The mathematical foundations of quantum theory are a matter of intense debate. The most prominent reconstruction programs are due to von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke. They all attempt to provide a purely categorical axiomatization of quantum theory. In this paper we provide a categorical characterization of Hilbert space and the category of operators on it. This resolves a question raised in these programs.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we compare the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species to the genome of the less reduced cnidarian parasite, Polypodium hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. These findings have implications for understanding the evolution of parasitism and the origin of the parasitic lifestyle. (Show more)

The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has caused more than 200,000 deaths in the United States and has affected millions of people worldwide. The virus responsible for this pandemic, SARS-CoV-2, is able to evade the antiviral action of the immune system by blocking the nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2, two key transcription factors that are essential for the induction of ISGs. Our results show that SARS-CoV-2 uses a previously unknown mechanism to block nuclear import of cargo proteins, which is mediated by the viral accessory protein Orf6. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the antiviral action of IFN and may lead to the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by the middle of the 21st century, and food production will have to increase by 70% to feed this population. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, but the impact of temperature variability on yield is not well understood. Here, we show that the variability of maize yields will increase substantially as the Earth’s temperature is increased, and that this variability will increase even if the mean yield remains constant. This variability will increase the risk of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in the world’s major maize-exporting countries, and will likely lead to rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of quantifying diet composition at the species level. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that, despite being similar in body size and digestive physiology, these species differed in their proportional grass consumption, dietary overlap, and diet composition. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in large mammal assemblages, and that diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results also highlight the importance of plant diversity in structuring large mammal communities.

We conducted a large survey of small businesses to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, businesses have widely differing beliefs about the length of the crisis. Finally, many businesses are financially fragile, and many anticipate problems accessing the CARES Act.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic on the open ocean surface is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the Sun is still a matter of debate. The most widely accepted scenario is that the Sun formed from a molecular cloud by gravitational collapse. However, the formation of the Sun is not the only goal of this process. The formation of the Sun is also a unique laboratory to study the formation of the first stars and planets in the universe.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the amount of energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of sociality. We show that the evolution of domestication and allonursing can increase the amount of energy available to the mother, and that this increase is associated with an increase in reproductive output. We also show that the increase in reproductive output is not due to an increase in resource availability, but rather an increase in metabolic power. This suggests that the evolution of sociality may be limited by the mother’s metabolic capacity rather than resource availability.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the substantia nigra. The disease is characterized by the presence of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in the striatum of a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of the different forms of α-syn, including its oligomers. In addition, VX-765 is able to preserve the nigrostriatal dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to slow down the progression of MSA. This would be achieved by limiting the accumulation of α-syn in the brain. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are specialized to detect and respond to specific stimuli. The endothelium is also responsible for controlling vascular tone, hemostasis, and inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of cells that are connected by a network of communication. The network is designed to be both local and global in nature, and to be efficient in the transmission of information. The network is also designed to be robust and to quickly respond to changes in the environment.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been accompanied by a vast amount of data, much of which is publicly available. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the information they contain is not always easy to interpret. We describe the COVIDcast API, a publicly available software package that provides access to a large number of public health and behavioral data signals, all of which are available at a fine geographic resolution. The data are updated daily, and the package tracks all revisions to historical data. The data are available in a common format, and we provide examples demonstrating that the data can be used to track the pandemic, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. Inactivation of these channels is essential for their function, but it is also responsible for the development of drug resistance. Inactivation is regulated by the selectivity filter, which is the narrowest part of the channel. We have studied the structural and functional properties of a mutant potassium channel that is unable to inactivate.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to be important for the health of the host. However, the role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host is not well understood. One of the most important aspects of the gut microbiome is the diversity of the organisms that inhabit the gut. The diversity of the gut microbiome is thought to be important for the health of the host, but the mechanisms by which the diversity of the gut microbiome is maintained are not well understood. Here, we show that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, synthesize natural products that could be used to regulate the diversity of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social groups, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchy remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We provide evidence that high-anxious animals are less likely to become dominant and that this is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We also show that nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3, can prevent the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious animals. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in social behavior and may lead to the development of new treatments for anxiety-related social disorders. (Show more)

The design of mechanical systems with desired responses is a fundamental problem in the field of mechanics. However, the design of a single system with a specific response is still challenging. In this work, we propose a method to synthesize a large number of mechanical systems with arbitrary responses through a digital synthesis approach. The synthesized systems are then manufactured into structures with complex shapes and materials. The structures are finally assembled into architectures with highly complex responses. The proposed method can be used to design mechanical systems with specific responses for specific applications.

The hemoglobin system is a major target of evolution and is a key component of the human condition. The hemoglobin system is also a major target of the aging process. In this study, we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is expressed in the human fetus and is down-regulated during the transition to adulthood. IGF2BP1 is a key component of the heterochronic let-7 miRNA pathway and is required for the silencing of beta-globin and up-regulation of gamma-globin in the developing fetus. In addition, IGF2BP1 mediates the down-regulation of BCL11A, a key regulator of fetal hemoglobin expression. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. This mechanism may be important for understanding the effects of aging on the hemoglobin system. (Show more)

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation, which is highly relevant to cancer. We found that cancer cells with mutations in the PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway, which are highly prevalent in human cancer, are resistant to ferroptosis. This resistance is mediated by activation of the SREBP1/SCD1 pathway, which promotes lipogenesis and thus ferroptosis resistance. We also found that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction is effective in preclinical models of cancer. These results suggest that ferroptosis-inducing agents may be useful in combination with mTORC1 inhibitors for the treatment of cancer. (Show more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure, and the use of antihypertensive drugs is increasing. However, the use of these drugs is associated with the development of cardiovascular complications. The present study shows that the use of antihypertensive drugs can lead to the development of cardiovascular remodeling. The study also shows that the use of antihypertensive drugs can lead to the development of cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the United States. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of forest birds, but that the policy has not yet been effective in reversing the long-term population declines of older-forest–associated species. We also show that the early-seral ecosystem, which is the focus of the recently proposed Forest Plan revision, is not a panacea for biodiversity conservation.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibiotics is urgently needed to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new acylide antibiotics. We used a combination of in silico and in vitro methods to screen a library of 10,000 compounds. The best candidate was tested in vivo and showed activity against resistant pathogens. This study demonstrates the potential of computational drug design for the discovery of new antibiotics. We introduce a new network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures. The proposed architecture is able to capture features at different scales, and is able to adapt to different problems. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice, and can be used to solve a wide range of problems. The proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several segmentation problems.

The evolution of the Lake Malawi cichlid fish species flock is a classic example of the effects of environmental change on biological evolution. Here we show that the dramatic changes in the climate of the tropics, which occurred at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, had a profound influence on the ecology of the lake and the evolution of the fish species flock.

The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become ubiquitous in many countries. This study shows that the use of such devices can have a negative impact on sleep, with implications for health, safety, and performance.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a 100-m drop in temperature that occurred 12,900 years ago. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with terrestrial sources, and that the spherules are derived from a source in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity is dependent on the stage of the immune system in which it is deleted.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a combination of phylogenomics and transcriptomics to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, and to trace the evolution of beetles and their plant-feeding habits. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cellulase enzymes. These results have important implications for understanding the evolution of insect diversity and the evolution of plant tissues. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of effective vaccines and therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 and other emerging viruses. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The APOE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor for late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD). APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk, and APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk. Here, we show that APOE isoform is also associated with the rate of astrocytic phagocytosis of synapses, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. We also show that APOE4 is associated with increased C1q accumulation in the brain, which may be due to the increased rate of phagocytosis of senescent synapses by astrocytes. These studies reveal a novel role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, and suggest that APOE4 may be associated with increased AD risk due to defective astrocytic phagocytosis of senescent synapses. They also suggest the hypothesis that AD susceptibility of APOE4 may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be a two-step process, in which the first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron, which is metastable at the core conditions. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its evolution. They also provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and its evolution.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels in the brain. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and may contribute to the addictive behaviors associated with marijuana use.
We show that the most powerful artificial neural networks in the world can be used to understand the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a very successful approach to machine learning, but it is still not clear why it works. In this paper, we show that the stability of the network is a key factor in the success of DL. We prove that there are problems where no algorithm can find a stable network with a given accuracy, even if we allow for a polynomial number of parameters. This is a fundamental difference between DL and traditional machine learning, where we can always find a stable network with a given accuracy. This result has implications for the design of DL algorithms and also for the theory of machine learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic has become a textbook example of how exponential growth can lead to a disaster. The same is true for the 1987 classic experiment by the psychologist Daniel Kahneman, who showed that people fail to understand exponential growth. However, the experiment’s design flaws were not recognized at the time. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for centuries, and the causative agent has been known for over a century. However, the identity of the pathogen has only recently been determined. The genome sequence of the leprosy bacillus, Mycobacterium leprae, has been published, and it is now known that it is a distinct species, Mycobacterium leprae. The genome sequence also reveals that the leprosy bacillus has undergone extensive reductive evolution, and that the pathogen has retained the ability to cause disease in the peripheral nervous system. In contrast, the genome of a new leprosy pathogen, M. lepromatosis, is very similar to that of the human pathogen, M. leprae, and the two pathogens are closely related. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. (Show more)

The entanglement dynamics of interacting quantum many-body systems is a long-standing open problem. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics of the Heisenberg spin chain can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the entanglement dynamics in the scaling limit of infinite system size and large time. We check our result for the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg spin chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5 million people worldwide. The development of a safe and effective vaccine is urgently needed to control the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate, COVI-VAC, that is highly attenuated and protects hamsters from lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. This vaccine candidate is expected to be safe and effective in humans and can be manufactured at large scale.

The Second Pandemic of plague (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. We developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector, which is the first of its kind. We found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for studying the historical spread of plague in Europe. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal cognition. However, it is not the only factor that determines the cognitive abilities of animals. In this study, we show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive abilities of animals. We show that the evolution of brain size is not the only factor that determines the cognitive abilities of animals.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria is more complex than previously appreciated. We have shown that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study also provides a mechanism for the observed TRAP1-mediated increase in invasiveness. (Show more)

Actin filaments are the major components of the cytoskeleton, and they are also the substrate for many biological processes. In this work, we show that actin filaments are severed by cofilin far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often consumed in excess. The present study shows that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of action of sweeteners and may have clinical relevance for the treatment of obesity.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island was colonized by different waves of people from different parts of Africa and Asia. The population structure is also influenced by geography, with a few centuries being sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results are important for understanding the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean region. They also provide a framework for the study of human diversity in the future.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but is controversial in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These results have implications for the design of social media platforms, and for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

The study of RNA modifications has been a major focus of research in the past decade. This work focuses on the impact of one of the most common modifications found in coding regions, pseudouridine (Ψ), on protein synthesis. We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our results have implications for the study of RNA modifications in cells and for the design of therapeutic RNAs.

We show that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of vertebrates into the water. We show that the evolution of aquatic mammals is driven to a common size in the water, and that this size is constrained by the energetics of feeding and thermoregulation.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a more efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that this is not the case in mouse airway cells, where rhinovirus replicates more robustly at the cool temperature of the nasal cavity. We demonstrate that this is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must sense and respond to changes in the external conditions. In this study, we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of the surface on which it is growing. This sensing mechanism is essential for the regulation of surface attachment, virulence, and biofilm formation.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the presence of pesticides in surface water and the risk for aquatic biodiversity. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is not reflected in the monitoring data. The presence of pesticides in surface water is high, and the risk for aquatic biodiversity is high, too. This study provides a basis for the development of effective strategies to reduce the use of pesticides in agriculture and to protect surface water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human health and the global economy. The virus has also spread to animals, including wildlife, and the potential for spillover back to humans is a major concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer, and that the virus has likely spread between humans and deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, evolution, and transmission of SARS-CoV-2. The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the number of affected individuals is expected to increase dramatically in the coming decades. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide and the neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) composed of the hyperphosphorylated form of the microtubule-associated protein tau. In this study, we show that neurons, which are the primary cell type affected in AD, are capable of producing a variety of inflammatory factors, including cytokines, chemokines, and proteases. These factors may play a critical role in the initiation of the AD-related immune response, which is most often attributed to sustained microglial activation in response to Aβ plaque deposits and cell death. Our results suggest that the accumulation of Aβ within neurons may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis.

The domestic chicken is one of the most widespread and important domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still missing. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread and practiced on a large scale at that site. We further show that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. The folding of a protein is a complex process, and the details are not known for most proteins. However, the folding of a few proteins has been studied in great detail, and the results can be used to understand the folding of other proteins. The maltose binding protein (MBP) is one such protein. We have studied the folding of MBP in great detail, and the results can be used to understand the folding of other proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a mechanism by which bacteria can adapt to such conditions. However, the cellular conditions that lead to the production of Np4 and the mechanism by which it functions as a stress response are not well understood. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing the cap structure from Np4, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions that enable Np4 to accumulate. We also show that the cap structure is recognized by ApaH in a manner distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, and that this enzyme has the potential to play a major role in the degradation of Np4-capped RNAs. These findings have implications for our understanding of the cellular response to stress and the potential for manipulating it for therapeutic purposes. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. Although the immune system is the main target of sepsis, the underlying mechanisms are complex and not fully understood. In this study, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also demonstrate that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation and decreasing immunosuppression during sepsis. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the immune response and clinical outcome in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the biomass of animals is mainly concentrated in the deep subsurface. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) in which the dynamics are continuous and the system is described by a continuous function. We show that this model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is also a material with a large bandgap, which is a major obstacle for its use in optoelectronic devices. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, by applying a large strain. This finding opens up new possibilities for the design of optoelectronic devices based on diamond.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is a rapidly developing field. The discovery of the structure of the first peptide in 1953, and the subsequent elucidation of the structure of the first protein in 1955, led to the development of the field of protein chemistry. The discovery of the structure of the first peptide in 2018, and the subsequent elucidation of the structure of the first protein in 2018, led to the development of the field of peptide chemistry. This paper describes the structure and antifungal activity of a unique peptide, and illustrates the potential of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide.

The male–female reproductive axis is a model system for understanding the molecular basis of sexual selection. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm by providing a source of proteins that support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. (Show more)

The protein von Willebrand factor (VWF) is essential for blood clotting, but its function is limited by its instability. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD), and the A1 domain is the target of platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) for binding. We show that force can switch the A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for platelet binding. This mechanism is important for the function of VWF in vivo. The force dependence of the switch is consistent with the behavior of a molecular switch. The switch is also important for understanding the effects of mutations in VWF. The force dependence of the switch is important for understanding the behavior of molecular switches.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the study of viruses in the human microbiome, and is a resource for the study of viruses in the human body.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system, but it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The observations of this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the ACI over Beijing. The observations show that increased aerosol loading led to increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius, but had no discernible increase on liquid water path. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI research.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface of the Earth has been estimated from isotopic data to have decreased from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean to the present ∼15 °C. However, this interpretation has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. We here present thermostability measurements of ancestral enzymes, which are compatible with a hot early Earth, and show that the ancestral environmental temperatures determined for these organisms are consistent with the temperature history inferred from isotopic data. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Show more)

Ion channels are the gatekeepers of the cell, and their pore gates are the key to their function. In this study, we found that the large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel has a unique mechanism of closing, which is state-dependent and is closed by the closed state itself. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels and may help to understand the mechanism of the BK channel’s normal closing and its physiological function. This study also provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels and may help to understand the mechanism of the BK channel’s normal closing and its physiological function. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that has plagued humans for thousands of years. Despite the development of antimalarial drugs, the disease remains a major global health problem. The malaria parasite, Plasmodium, is able to invade the human red blood cell (RBC) and establish a blood stage infection. The invasion process is a complex event that involves a number of parasite proteins interacting with the host cell. Here, we show that one of these proteins, EBA175, alters the physical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is the first time that we have been able to show that the parasite alters the physical properties of the host cell, suggesting that invasion is a complex process that involves a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies. It is also a material with a large bandgap, which is a major obstacle for its use in optoelectronic devices. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely closed, by applying a large strain. This finding opens up new possibilities for the design of optoelectronic devices based on diamond.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza virus outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in humidity. While low ambient humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our study provides insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome, which may be useful for the development of strategies to reduce influenza-associated morbidity and mortality.
