The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. Whether and how the brain does this, however, remains largely unknown. Here, we show that the brain responds to the addition of each word in a sentence with a sudden increase in high-gamma power, which is consistent with a merge operation. We also show that the brain responds to the addition of each word with a decrease in low-gamma power, which is consistent with a decrease in the probability of the word given the rest of the sentence. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is consistent with a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results have implications for the study of language and sentence processing in the brain. They also suggest that the brain may use a combination of probability and merge operations to build syntactic structures.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are regulated differently at the transcriptional and proteostatic level, which can be used to regulate the pathway in different tissues. This study provides a mechanism for the regulation of redundant genes and may be used to understand the regulation of other redundant genes in vertebrates.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. In this study, we show that stimulation of LH neurons causes rapid vigorous eating in sated animals. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, and that it is not involved in the regulation of body weight.

Nitrogen is the primary limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil is a key trait for plants to acquire. However, the ability to fix nitrogen in the soil is limited to a few species, and the process is inefficient. We have developed a system that allows plants to control the activity of nitrogen-fixing bacteria, and thus the acquisition of nitrogen, in a manner that is specific to the plant species and does not affect other plant species. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a step toward the development of a sustainable agriculture.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

We show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear the sounds of prey and predators, and even the sounds of its own footsteps, by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web is a self-manufactured, acoustic antenna that is much more sensitive to sound than the spider itself. The spider can also adjust the size and shape of the web to detect sounds from different directions. This study provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of hearing, and the spider’s web provides a new platform for studying acoustic sensing and acoustic flow detection. The spider’s web can also be used as a model system for studying the regeneration of the external body. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of hearing and the design of acoustic sensors. (Show more)

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been devastating, and the need for a safe and effective vaccine is urgent. We report the design, synthesis, and evaluation of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein, which mediates viral entry to cells, that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. The variant exhibits high-affinity binding to ACE2, and antibodies raised against the variant protein exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD from two recently reported SARS-CoV-2 variants of concern. Presentation of the variant on a virus-like particle also reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the variant may be a useful component of a vaccine for global access. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALK/ALKALS family of receptors is implicated in the development of a variety of human cancers. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALKALS can activate the ALK/ALKALS family of receptors in vivo. We further show that the ALKALS are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALS in the development of human cancer and in the regulation of neural crest-derived tissues.

The emergence of plague as a devastating human pathogen is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution and spread are still largely unknown. Here, we present a large dataset of ancient Yersinia pestis genomes, which allowed us to explore the diversity of this pathogen during the formative period of its evolution. We find that the emergence of plague was a multistep process, with a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage, followed by the emergence of a flea-adapted form. We also find that plague spread rapidly across Eurasia, with a strong correlation between time and geographic distance. These data provide insights into the early evolution and ecology of plague, and its rapid spread across Eurasia. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and their support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. We found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the political and social consequences of the endorsement of HM.

The management of agricultural systems can influence the amount of carbon (C) stored in the soil. However, the effects of these practices on soil C dynamics are highly uncertain, especially on grassland-derived soils. We show that soil health management practices can increase the amount of C stored in the soil, but the effects are highly dependent on the management system and the region. These results highlight the importance of managing grasslands for soil C storage and the potential of rotational grazing to increase soil C in the Midwest. This study provides a framework for understanding the effects of agricultural management on soil C dynamics and can be used to develop climate-smart agricultural systems. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize viruses with the greatest potential to spill over to humans. We then used this framework to prioritize viruses for investigation, and created a web tool to make this information accessible to the public. We hope that this tool will be used to inform research and public health interventions to prevent future outbreaks.

Nectar is the reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination. The color of nectar is often used as a proxy for the color of the reward, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a similar alkaloid in the red nectar of Jaltomata herrerae, a hummingbird-visited species. Our findings suggest that the red color of nectar is a convergent trait, and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides insight into the evolution of a key trait in plant–pollinator interactions. (Show more)

We have sequenced genomes from 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. We find that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with that of modern northern and central Europeans, but that of women is very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we sequenced a total of 486 functional variants in all individuals, which revealed that women with artificial skull deformations had a genetic ancestry that was very different from that of the rest of the population. This example of female-biased migration indicates that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. Our findings provide insights into the origin and evolution of MERS-CoV and may help design strategies to prevent future zoonotic outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) is a feasible and effective approach to pathogen surveillance in resource-scarce settings. We demonstrate the ability to detect a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens in a single test. We also show that mNGS can be used to identify the presence of pathogens in a population, and to monitor the emergence of pathogens over time. This approach can be used to better understand the regional pathogen landscape and to deploy rapid public health response.

The human genome is replicated in a process called DNA replication that is essential for the proper functioning of all organisms. The process is carried out by a complex of proteins and DNA polymerases called the replisome. In this study, we have developed a series of assays to measure the processivity and stability of the replisome. We find that the replisome is stable and has a high processivity.

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. In this paper, we report the first in vitro evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme, which can replicate RNA from an RNA template. This work represents a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities in the future.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients were analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab was evaluated. The results showed that tocilizumab could improve the clinical condition of severe and critical COVID-19 patients, and the mortality rate was significantly reduced. This study provides a reference for the clinical treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to sequester copper is well established, but the role of these mechanisms in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and in the regulation of interactions with competing microbes is not well understood. Here we demonstrate that the xan BGC-derived isocyanide metabolites of Aspergillus fumigatus bind copper and have antimicrobial properties. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is a source of fungal copper homeostasis molecules and that the fungal ability to sequester copper may be an important factor in the regulation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of interactions with competing microbes and may lead to the development of new antifungal agents. (Show more)

The presence of tridymite, a high-temperature, high-pressure polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary rock at the surface of Mars is surprising. The sedimentary rock is part of a larger body of work on the origin of the Martian surface, and the formation of silica-rich minerals in sedimentary environments.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of forests and agricultural crops, and it is expected to increase in the future due to climate change. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is already changing in Europe and Asia, and that this change is expected to increase in North America. We also show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is determined by the leaf-out and leaf-freezing strategies of trees, and that these strategies are shaped by the geographic distribution of frost damage. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease, but the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. We show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, we demonstrate that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Our findings have important implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce induced astrocytes from living ALS patients, which can be used to study disease mechanisms and screen for therapeutics. We show that astrocytes from ALS patients are toxic to motor neurons, and that this toxicity is shared between patients with different genetic causes of ALS. This method will enable rapid screening of drugs to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity, and thus accelerate the development of therapies for ALS. This work will also help to understand the role of astrocytes in other neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks is a complex community of bacteria, fungi, and viruses that is thought to protect the tick from pathogens. However, the mechanisms by which the gut microbiota influences the tick’s ability to transmit pathogens are poorly understood. We now show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the gut microbiota and facilitates the pathogen’s transmission to the vertebrate host. These data provide a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen can influence the gut microbiota of its vector to enhance transmission. This work also highlights the importance of studying the interactions between pathogens and their vectors to understand the ecology and evolution of disease transmission. (Show more)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most iconic and enigmatic stories in evolution. The discovery of a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail (Pygostylia) provides new insights into the evolution of the avian bauplan.

The climate system is a coupled system, in which the atmosphere and the ocean are the main reservoirs of energy. The atmosphere is also a reservoir of water vapor, which is an important greenhouse gas. We show here that the water vapor in the stratosphere increases with the temperature of the troposphere, which implies that the stratospheric water vapor is a positive feedback to climate change.

Vertebrates have evolved a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and even to ultraviolet. However, the evolutionary history of the blue color is poorly understood. Here, we show that the occurrence of blue color in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of blue color in anurans, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our findings also provide a molecular basis for the evolution of blue color in other vertebrates. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a feature of many cancers, and the hypoxic tumor microenvironment is a major driver of cancer progression. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is increased in hypoxic cells, and NANOG-positive cells are enriched in the tumor microenvironment. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for cancer treatment.

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the extinction is coeval with a major reorganization of the carbon cycle. We use the age model provided by the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China, to explore the links between environmental perturbation, carbon cycle disruption, mass extinction, and recovery at millennial timescales. We find that the extinction was preceded by a reorganization of the carbon cycle, which persisted for ∼500 ka. The extinction was followed by a period of ecosystem recovery, but the cause of the extinction is unknown. The age model provided by the Global Stratotype Section and Point will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. (Show more)

The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier against the invasion of pathogens and the immune system. However, the intestinal epithelium is also the first site of immune attack in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), such as Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is essential for maintaining intestinal homeostasis and attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs). RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this epigenetic regulation could be beneficial to the treatment of chronic inflammatory diseases, including IBD. This study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. (Show more)

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and vaccines. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in the down-regulated conformation, which is the most prevalent in the virus. We show that the spike glycoprotein is in a more open conformation in the down-regulated conformation, which may facilitate binding to the receptor and fusion. These results may help to inform the design of vaccines and antibodies that can neutralize the virus. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic will result in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003, and a decline at age 65 y of 0.87 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry, and they are also of great interest in the field of materials science. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt are electron acceptors, while the elements right after them are electron donors. We also show that the elements preceding Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd are pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them are pseudo–metal atoms. These results are of fundamental importance in chemistry and materials science. Furthermore, we show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales are explicative and predictive.

We show that changes in human demography can reduce global fire activity, which in turn can reduce warming. However, this effect is not guaranteed, and the risk of more extreme fires is not eliminated. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to understand the effects of climate, demography, and fire on the future evolution of the carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic bacteria through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, which is metabolized by the bacteria to enhance their ability to produce light at night. This glycan is provided only at dusk, when the squid is preparing to produce light, and is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbioses, and suggests that the provision of specific nutrients may be a more common mechanism for the maintenance of symbioses than previously thought. (Show more)

We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We show how to represent documents as topic sequences, and how to identify the gender bias of topics. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which killed an estimated 30–50% of the population of Europe in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The origin of this disease is still debated, but it is generally assumed that it was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of the bacterium, and that the climate in Europe was also suitable for the survival of the rodent reservoir. We find no evidence for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. Our results suggest that the introduction of the disease into Europe was the result of multiple reintroductions, which were delayed by 15 ± 1 y. (Show more)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a rapidly spreading disease that has caused the death of millions of sea stars worldwide. The disease is caused by a virus, but the identity of the virus has not been determined. Here, we show that a virus-sized material from symptomatic sea stars is able to cause the disease in healthy sea stars, suggesting that the virus is the cause of the disease. We also show that the virus is widespread in the environment and that it has been present on the Pacific Coast of North America for at least 72 y. These findings provide evidence that the virus is the cause of the disease and that the virus has been spreading with the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of more efficient therapies. We show that an antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is able to target AML stem cells and that this antibody is able to suppress the proliferation of primary AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Furthermore, the results indicate that the antibody is able to achieve antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Thus, the antibody is able to target both the leukemia stem cells and the leukemia cells, which is important for the development of more efficient therapies. This study provides important evidence for the development of antibody-based therapies for AML. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the island at high resolution, and we found that the island was settled by different waves of people from Africa and Asia, with a recent admixture of Europeans and Middle Eastern people. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, we found that the distribution of genetic diversity is influenced by geography, suggesting that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results help to understand the history of Madagascar and the settlement of the Indian Ocean. They also provide a framework for the study of the genetic structure of the island and the Indian Ocean. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a protein that interacts with a membrane-bound enzyme and increases its activity. We also show that the RNA can repress two genes by base pairing with their promoters. The RNA and protein compete for translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. These findings provide insight into the evolution of dual-function RNAs and the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against such variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work can help to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status, but their assessments are subjective and difficult to aggregate. We show that the USDA Crop Progress and Condition survey, which is based on the assessments of thousands of crop experts, can be transformed into a continuous, probabilistic variable that is better suited to quantitative analysis. We show that the resulting Crop Condition Index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed methodology can be applied to other agricultural commodities and countries, and can be used to monitor the impact of climate change on crop production.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural basis of language is still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the activity of single neurons. We show that the activity of a small number of neurons can be used to represent and process linguistic information. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key component of the evolution of photosynthesis and the origin of the first eukaryotes. The evolutionary history of the plastid genome is also a key component of the evolution of the plant lineage, as the plastid genome is maternally inherited. The evolutionary history of the plastid genome is also linked to the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle, which is the most successful lifestyle on Earth. We show that the evolution of the plastid genome is linked to the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle, and that the evolution of the parasitic lifestyle is linked to the evolution of photosynthesis. Our findings have implications for the evolution of the plant lineage and for the origin of the first eukaryotes. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 drought in southwestern South Africa was the worst in the last century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the probability of such a drought by a factor of five to six. This increase is expected to continue under high-emission scenarios, with the risk of drought increasing by a factor of 10 to 100 by the end of the century. This study highlights the importance of anthropogenic climate change in the risk of drought in SSA.

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. However, the conditions under which they are formed are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a new quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-harvesting pigments are the key to its success. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of these pigments, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, using different chemistries. Here we show that the O2-dependent enzyme is a subunit of the cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS) and experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE), and it is well known to be associated with neurodegenerative diseases. In this study, we found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. We also found that ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease, and activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Our findings suggest that glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a rationale for the development of cell-type–specific ASK1 inhibitors for the treatment of EAE. This study may also have implications for the development of cell-type–specific ASK1 inhibitors for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases. This study may also have implications for the development of cell-type–specific ASK1 inhibitors for the treatment of neurodegenerative diseases.

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the driest and warmest on record. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new treatments. This article is protected by copyright. This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but it also highlights the potential for more positive content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, and mutations in its components are associated with immune dysfunction and muscle disease. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1, which are associated with Stormorken syndrome, and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel, ORAI1, which is associated with a Stormorken-like syndrome. These mutations result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, and spontaneous bleeding accompanied by reduced numbers of thrombocytes in zebrafish embryos. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of many neurodegenerative diseases, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we show that the spread of protein aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on the internalization of aggregates and the subsequent accumulation of aggregates within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of lysosomes with the cell membrane. These results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus, and showed immunosuppressive activity. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system and the potential for MTX to be used as a therapeutic agent. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is essential for the generation of the one-carbon unit required for cell growth. We have also identified a metabolic deficiency of one of the most aggressive types of cancer, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results provide a metabolic target for cancer therapy, and a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma that may be exploited in the clinic. This work also provides a framework for the rational design of inhibitors of other enzymes that generate one-carbon units.

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS suggests that they are prone to aggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal is designed to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. The device can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for the study of many-body physics with neutral atoms. The photonic crystal system is a promising platform for the study of many-body physics with neutral atoms.

The study of the evolution of aquatic plants is of great interest because of the ecological and evolutionary importance of this group. The study of Montsechia, a plant from the Cretaceous, is of particular interest because it is the oldest known aquatic angiosperm.

The evolution of viruses is often studied using genetic sequences from modern viruses. However, viruses have been present on Earth for millions of years, and it is therefore of interest to study the evolution of viruses in the distant past. Here we present the first ancient viral sequences, which show that the ancestor of all currently circulating B19V strains is likely to have been present in humans at least 12.6 thousand years ago. We also show that the recombination event that formed the ancestor of all B19V strains occurred at least 5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, or 2.9 ± 0.8 cm/y. This rate is higher than the rate of rise implied by the IPCC AR5 models, which is due to the fact that the models do not account for the acceleration of sea level rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity, but fits a more general pattern seen in the ongoing erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950. If this trend continues, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms has been revolutionized by the development of NMR-assisted crystallography. This approach provides atomic-resolution characterization of stable intermediates in enzyme active sites, including hydrogen atom locations and tautomeric equilibria. Here, we use this integrated approach to characterize the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a detailed picture of structure and reactivity, highlighting the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole does not react, while benzimidazole is poised for, but unable to initiate, the subsequent bond formation step. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for the development of effective antiviral therapies. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is currently in clinical trials for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the further development of remdesivir for the treatment of MERS and other coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. In this study, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic bacteria through the strategic delivery of a single glycan, which is metabolized by the bacteria to enhance their ability to produce light at night. This glycan is provided only at dusk, when the squid is preparing to produce light, and is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a new perspective on the regulation of symbioses, and suggests that the provision of specific nutrients may be a more common mechanism for the maintenance of symbioses than previously thought. (Show more)

This paper reports on a series of experiments and field trials that test the impact of a brief, online intervention on teachers’ mindsets about discipline. The intervention is designed to encourage teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. The experiments show that teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions, and that these mindsets can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. We also identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II (termed Pro-Gate loop). The Pro-Gate loop faces toward the minor groove of RNA:DNA hybrid and is involved in modulating the translocation of minor-groove alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. This work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. These findings will be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a severe pathogen that causes severe pneumonia in humans. To better understand the mechanisms of MERS-CoV infection, we engineered viruses with mutations that blocked sequential proteolysis of the virus spike (S) glycoproteins. We found that these mutations affected virus infection into human lung-derived cells, but not into other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings may also be relevant to other viruses that require sequential proteolysis for infection.

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and is a major contributor to the environmental crisis. The food system also has a major impact on population health, with the majority of deaths worldwide being caused by diet-related conditions. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a large impact on meal selection behavior. This has the potential to have a significant impact on population health and the environment.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We have developed a method to measure the surfaceome of cancer cells, and applied it to six of the most common oncogenes. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of the surfaceome are harmonized by common themes such as up-regulation of nutrient transporters and down-regulation of adhesion molecules. We also find that the surfaceome is remodeled by the oncogenes, and that this is accompanied by changes to the glycoproteome. These studies provide a systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. (Show more)

In the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates, in line with previous estimates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global community. The molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique mechanism of immune suppression.

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a potentially life-threatening condition. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats, and that this is mediated, at least in part, by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The problem of selective inference is the challenge of assessing the strength of associations in a dataset that has been “cherry picked”—searched for the strongest associations. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data and complex statistical modeling. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for thinking about this problem and to illustrate its use in practice.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of the liver and other organs. However, the generation of vascular networks is still a major challenge. Here, we demonstrate that the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of vascular networks in the liver. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of vascular networks and the treatment of liver diseases. This study also provides a new approach for the generation of endothelial cells, which is important for the treatment of many diseases. (Show more)

The identification of ALK and LTK as “orphan” receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) has led to the development of a number of targeted therapies for a variety of cancers. However, the role of these RTKs in normal physiology has remained largely unexplored. Here, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK and LTK, augmentor, is essential for the development of the zebrafish pigment system. We also show that augmentor ligands are essential for the development of the eye and the skin. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and LTK and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate LTK in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a foundation for the development of new therapies for cancer and other diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for normal β-cell function, and its deficiency caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. These findings provide a new perspective for the treatment of T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza. They are divided into two groups, based on their genome organization. The group that causes human influenza has a segmented genome, which is packaged into virions by a selective mechanism. We identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus, which is required for optimal viral replication. This interaction is sequence specific and sequence dependent, and it favors the copackaging of interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that this interaction is a part of the selective packaging mechanism. The lack of conservation of this interaction among influenza A viruses might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the molecular details of the selective packaging mechanism. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in the arterial wall. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a multistep process that involves the accumulation of atheroprone phenotypes in the vascular wall. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) by disturbed flow is a critical step in the development of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential formation of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of athero-protective strategies. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the natural landscape for millions of years. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States, and the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially. We show that human activities have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire, and that human-caused wildfires are the dominant cause of wildfire in the United States. Actions to reduce the risk of wildfire and associated hazards should focus on reducing human-caused ignitions.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) the density of college-educated adults, (ii) the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and (iii) the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also provide a new way to measure the success of urban revitalization efforts.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion TRP channel as a receptor of natural repellents, and demonstrated its involvement in the avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods, and also helps to understand the evolution of insect–plant interaction. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Zika virus (ZIKV) has been linked to a number of severe health problems, including microcephaly and Guillain–Barré syndrome. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the virus is thought to replicate within individual cells for a period of time before being cleared from the cell and the host. Here we use a mathematical model to estimate the parameters of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV, allowing for a more complete understanding of the disease process. We also provide estimates of the efficacy of antiviral treatment, which can be used to guide clinical trials. This work provides a framework for understanding the disease process and for developing effective treatments. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In particular, the ongoing global warming is expected to trigger a breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, leading to the death of the coral host. Here, we show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. We provide evidence that the coral host is unable to cope with the increased metabolic demand during heat stress, which is compensated by the degradation of amino acids. This leads to a shift from net uptake to release of ammonium, which in turn promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. These processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is the primary barrier between the host and the environment. In the absence of this barrier, the host is susceptible to systemic infections and nutrient loss. In this study, we show that the intestinal epithelium is also the primary site of tumorigenesis in Drosophila. We identify a mechanism by which the tumor microenvironment triggers a regenerative response in the epithelium, which in turn triggers tumor growth. We also show that the regenerative response is dependent on the activity level of JNK signaling. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a model for the study of cancer-induced intestinal barrier dysfunction in mammals. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to it. We show that treatment with chemotherapy can increase the expression of the ROR1 receptor in breast cancer cells, which in turn can enhance the ability of breast cancer cells to survive chemotherapy, to form tumors, and to metastasize to the lungs. These effects can be reversed by treatment with the humanized anti-ROR1 antibody cirmtuzumab. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, which would have led to a reduction in Southern Hemisphere precipitation and a change in the Southern Hemisphere monsoon system. However, this attribution is based on a single proxy, and the timing of the change is not well constrained. We show that a series of massive volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation is highly likely to have led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn is likely to have caused a change in the Southern Hemisphere circulation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which we use to assess the role of inland fisheries in food security, biodiversity conservation, and fishery sustainability. We find that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, and that river basins with the highest biodiversity are also the most productive for fisheries. However, the high dependence of poor and undernourished populations on inland fisheries highlights the need to protect these resources from overfishing and degradation. Our data can be used to improve the sustainability of inland fisheries and to protect the ecosystems that provide food and livelihoods to hundreds of millions of people.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The material delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles.
