The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are largely incapable of regenerating after injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway, which is known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery provides a platform for the discovery of novel factors that control the intrinsic regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in populations and in the evolution of new traits. In this study, we provide a detailed view of the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant.

The brain is a highly interconnected network of functionally specialized regions. The study of the organization of this network is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we show that the metabolic organization of the resting brain is strongly related to the functional organization of the brain. This organization can be used to study the normal and pathological organization of the brain.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is essential for translation and stability of the mRNA. In addition, the cap structure is important for the recognition of the mRNA by the spliceosome and the ribosome. Here we show that the yeast genome contains a second modification at the 5′ end of mRNA, the nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) group.

Metabolic memory is the phenomenon of prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the study of metabolic memory. These epigenetic changes are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the maintenance of the beneficial effects of intensive therapy.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer, and the current treatment options are limited. In this study, we identified a role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in the sensitivity to chemotherapy in TNBC. We show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high rate of relapse. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and craving. Moreover, the gut microbiota is altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut–brain axis is involved in the development of alcohol dependence, and that the gut microbiota is a previously unidentified target in the management of this disorder.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, which are responsible for the characteristic aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the only known nitrogenous volatiles are derived from the amino acid cysteine. Here we report the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of a wide range of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This pathway is unique to tomato and is likely to be of general importance in the biosynthesis of nitrogenous volatiles in other Solanaceae.

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We also show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation, and its functional organization is poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC and parasubiculum during free-running behavior in mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be essential for navigation, are strongly coupled to each other, but not to border, head-direction, or object-vector cells. These results suggest that grid cells may have a distinct organization from other cell types in the MEC. This work provides a new approach to studying the organization of the MEC and its connections to other brain regions. It also provides a platform for future studies of the functional organization of the MEC and its connections to other brain regions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of factors, including environmental cues, such as day length. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) can function as an interplant flowering signal, which is able to synchronize the flowering of hosts and parasites. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigro–striato–nigral loop form specialized integrative units within the system. These units, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are composed of striosomal fibers that receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making. We suggest that the striosome–dendron bouquets are critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this paper, we show that the speed at which people respond to each other can be used to predict how connected they feel to each other. This is a signal that is used by others to judge the quality of the connection between two people.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. It is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for the generation of the electrical impulse. In this study, we show that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the SAN and regulates the function of these cells. We found that STIM1 is required for the maintenance of the SAN function. Our results suggest that STIM1 is a regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells and contributes to the automaticity of the SAN. These findings may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of arrhythmia. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plants, but its function in plant physiology has been debated. In this study, we show that Si can enhance plant resistance against insect herbivory, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense responses. This study provides a new perspective on the function of Si in plant physiology and may lead to the development of new strategies for improving plant resistance against insect herbivory. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the function of macrophages.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that is thought to be mediated by the brain. However, the neural basis of language is still poorly understood. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the activity of single neurons. We show that the activity of a small number of neurons can be used to represent and process linguistic information. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenge due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Here, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules to plants, and we show that the size, shape, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for plant cell internalization and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work also provides a platform for the delivery of biomolecules to plants for the study of plant biology and the development of plant-based biotechnologies.

The world’s largest lakes are often viewed as remote and distant from human activities, but this study shows that the nutrient inputs from small streams can be locally important. We show that the majority of the nutrients delivered to the world’s fifth largest lake come from a small number of large tributaries, but that the nutrients from smaller tributaries are more biologically available and could fuel algal blooms in the nearshore zone. Our findings highlight the importance of small streams in driving coastal eutrophication, and suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to include these areas.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the dynamics of a system of coupled oscillators, and we show that the network can be modeled as a network of coupled oscillators. We also show that the network can be simulated efficiently using a network of coupled oscillators. This article is the first in a series of articles that will study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in the presence of a thermodynamic forcing that is available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations.

We show that NMDAR-Ab encephalitis is associated with changes in the EEG, and that these changes are driven by changes in the intrinsic microcircuitry of the brain. This work offers a mechanistic understanding of the relationship between the EEG and the underlying brain activity, and may help to guide the development of new therapies.

The history of abrupt climate change is a key component of the Earth system, and the history of the C cycle is a key component of the climate system. Here, we present a study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period.

The palm oil industry is the largest consumer of tropical deforestation-associated carbon emissions, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the leading certification body. We show that RSPO certification is associated with a 33% reduction in deforestation in oil palm plantations, but that certification has no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Certification appears to be most effective in reducing deforestation in areas that are already converted to oil palm. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not yet a viable tool for halting tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is involved in the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the release of proteins and vesicles from the plasma membrane. In humans, the exocyst complex is involved in the development of cancer and diabetes. In plants, the exocyst complex is involved in the development of flowers and fruits. However, the molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex in plants is still unknown. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the exocyst component of 70 kDa (EXO70) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

In many vertebrates, the sex of an individual is determined by a single genetic locus. In species with a single sex determination allele, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at that locus. In species with multiple sex determination alleles, the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at multiple loci. Here we show that the sex of an individual in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii is determined by the genotype at two sex determination loci, and that the sex of an individual is determined by the genotype at four sex determination loci.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by both oxygen and light. The retina is also a site of high oxidative stress, which is a major contributor to age-related vision loss. In this study, we show that the redox active metal iron (Fe) is important for the health of the retina. We also show that Fe is important for the health of the retinal pigment epithelium, which is the cell type that is responsible for the removal of metabolic byproducts from the photoreceptor cells. This study provides insight into the role of Fe in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapies for age-related vision loss. (show more)

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystem functioning, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a key process in the development of biodiversity. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, and the mechanisms that drive the diversification of predator feeding strategies are poorly understood. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is linked to the evolution of their prey, and that this process is not a dead end. Our findings contribute to understanding the evolution of predator specialization, and the mechanisms that drive the diversification of predator feeding strategies.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is fragmentary, however, and the earliest hominin fossils are only 800,000 years old. Here we show that the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, was present in a 1.42-Myr-old hominin fossil from Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study thus provides a new perspective on the evolution of the human hand. (Show more)

Cancer is a disease of rapid cell growth, and the one-carbon unit is essential for this process. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT), which is essential for the generation of the one-carbon unit required for cell growth. We have also identified a metabolic deficiency of one of the most aggressive types of cancer, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. These results provide a metabolic target for cancer therapy, and a metabolic vulnerability of lymphoma that may be exploited in the clinic. This work also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of one-carbon unit inhibitors in cancer therapy.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the resulting loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services is well documented. However, the impact of deforestation on people’s diets is less well understood. We show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this can be mitigated by the presence of forests. This study has important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in meeting nutrition goals, as well as other environmental and conservation goals.

The mechanization of agriculture has greatly increased the capacity of farm machinery, allowing for higher output and higher yields. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
